newsitem.title: UK: Eskom sets first rand Eurobond for SAfrican issuer.
newsitem.headline: Eskom sets first rand Eurobond for SAfrican issuer.

text.p: State-owned electricity utility Eskom Ltd launched the first rand-denominated Eurobond from a South African borrower on Tuesday.
"This issue marks the first South African parastatal borrower to issue in the euro rand market since its opening in September 1995," underwriter Hambros Bank said in a statement.

"The bond differs from existing domestic Eskom bonds held offshore in that this issue will be available in bearer form, with physical delivery, and can be cleared through Euroclear and Cedel," Hambros said.
The 150 million rand five-year bond pays an annual 15.0 percent coupon.
The bond has an annual yield of 15.34 percent, which is equivalent to the South African government bond curve, Hambros said.
Eskom cancelled plans in February to launch a mark-denominated five-year Eurobond due to the inability to obtain forward foreign exchange cover.
Hambros said Eskom actively markets its existing debt outside South Africa, with 40 to 50 percent of its debt held offshore. It has issued bonds in dollars, marks, Swiss francs and yen.
Eskom generates over 97 percent of South Africa's electricity and more than half the total capacity consumed in Africa combining generation, transmission, supply and distribution.
In terms of nominal generation capacity, Eskom is the world's fourth largest utility.
Eskom debt, denominated in rand, carries a Baa1 rating from Moody's Investors Service and a BBB+ rating from Standard and Poor's.
In January, the first South African-based subsidiary entered the Eurorand market with a 100 million rand four-year Eurobond.

German chemicals and drugs group subsidiary Bayer Pty Ltd -- which is wholly-owned and has a support agreement from its parent Bayer AG -- launched the deal via lead manager Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in London.
The paper pays a 15.375 percent coupon.
